name: The Ledger Page
summary: Physical proof of Smith's Coster's involvement with MS-13 mindersand.
details: I have a ledger page tying Smith's Coster to MS-13 mindersand and 'increase compliance' intent notes. If it surfaces, everything changes. If it's destroyed, the proof is gone.
trigger: Someone asks about proof, or Meilin needs leverage, or Smith's Coster demands it back.
escalation: Pryce intensifies pursuit. Adjacent people become targets. The crew learns they're carrying heat.

name: Violent Reaction
summary: Mindersand affects Meilin far more violently than most people.
details: Most people exposed to mindersand fog quietly. Meilin's body tried to kill her. She's a walking early warning system and a liability in the same breath.
trigger: Exposure to contaminated food, water, or air. Someone weaponizes her sensitivity.
escalation: Medical emergency. Cover blown. Someone realizes she's useful as a detector... or a victim.

name: Pressure Points
summary: Her father, Sera, and Meredin's network can all be squeezed.
details: Any pressure on Kaito, Sera Quill, or Meredin's network forces Meilin to choose between speed and safety. She'll sacrifice herself before she lets them pay for her choices.
trigger: A message arrives. An audit targets the shop. Sera is followed. Meredin goes quiet.
escalation: Meilin makes a bad trade to protect someone. The crew inherits the consequences.

name: Brother's Return
summary: Cassian can re-enter her life at any port, and his 'help' has strings.
details: Cassian can show up through a port, a ship contract, or a patron's introduction. His opportunities often come with invisible strings attached.
trigger: The party docks somewhere. A patron offers help. A letter arrives with bright words and one wrong line.
escalation: Cassian's 'favor' creates a debt. His patron has expectations. Family loyalty conflicts with crew safety.

name: Pattern Obsession
summary: She can't let go of something that doesn't make sense.
details: If something doesn't match the pattern, Meilin will keep pulling until she understands it, even when she should stop. This has saved lives. It has also nearly ended hers.
trigger: A detail doesn't add up. Someone's story has a gap. The 'obvious' answer is too clean.
escalation: She stays too long. Asks the wrong question. Puts herself (or others) in danger chasing the thread.
